P6499.label: literate population
P6499.description: number of literate people within a territorial entity (typically determined during a census)

P6897.label: literacy rate
P6897.description: percentage of the population that is not illiterate

P100001.label: net ODA received
P100001.description: Net official development assistance is disbursement flows (net of repayment of principal) that meet the DAC definition of ODA and are made to countries and territories on the DAC list of aid recipients.

P100002.label: access to electricity
P100002.description: Access to electricity, urban is the percentage of urban population with access to electricity.

P100003.label: prevalence of undernourishment (% of population)
P100003.description: Population below minimum level of dietary energy consumption (also referred to as prevalence of undernourishment) shows the percentage of the population whose food intake is insufficient to meet dietary energy requirements continuously. Data showing as 5 may signify a prevalence of undernourishment below 5%.

P100007.label: people using at least basic drinking water services (% of population)
P100007.description: The percentage of people using at least basic water services.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic water services as well as those using safely managed water services.  Basic drinking water services is defined as drinking water from an improved source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a round trip.  Improved water sources include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, and packaged or delivered water.

P100008.label: people using at least basic sanitation services (% of population)
P100008.description: The percentage of people using at least basic sanitation services, that is, improved sanitation facilities that are not shared with other households.  This indicator encompasses both people using basic sanitation services as well as those using safely managed sanitation services.   Improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, compositing toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

P100009.label: mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000 live births)
P100009.description: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.

P100013.label: group grievance
P100013.description: The Group Grievance Indicator focuses on divisions and schisms between different groups in society ? particularly divisions based on social or political characteristics ? and their role in access to services or resources, and inclusion in the political process. Group Grievance may also have a historical component, where aggrieved communal groups cite injustices of the past, sometimes going back centuries, that influence and shape that group?s role in society and relationships with other groups. This history may in turn be shaped by patterns of real or perceived atrocities or ?crimes? committed with apparent impunity against communal groups. Groups may also feel aggrieved because they are denied autonomy, self-determination or political independence to which they believe they are entitled. The Indicator also considers where specific groups are singled out by state authorities, or by dominant groups, for persecution or repression, or where there is public scapegoating of groups believed to have acquired wealth, status or power ?illegitimately?, which may manifest itself in the emergence of fiery rhetoric, such as through ?hate? radio, pamphleteering, and stereotypical or nationalistic political speech., The Group Grievance Indicator focuses on divisions and schisms between different groups in society � particularly divisions based on social or political characteristics � and their role in access to services or resources, and inclusion in the political process. Group Grievance may also have a historical component, where aggrieved communal groups cite injustices of the past, sometimes going back centuries, that influence and shape that group�s role in society and relationships with other groups. This history may in turn be shaped by patterns of real or perceived atrocities or �crimes� committed with apparent impunity against communal groups. Groups may also feel aggrieved because they are denied autonomy, self-determination or political independence to which they believe they are entitled. The Indicator also considers where specific groups are singled out by state authorities, or by dominant groups, for persecution or repression, or where there is public scapegoating of groups believed to have acquired wealth, status or power �illegitimately�, which may manifest itself in the emergence of fiery rhetoric, such as through �hate� radio, pamphleteering, and stereotypical or nationalistic political speech.

P100020.label: demographic pressures
P100020.description: The Demographic Pressures Indicator considers pressures upon the state deriving from the population itself or the environment around it. For example, the Indicator measures population pressures related to food supply, access to safe water, and other life-sustaining resources, or health, such as prevalence of disease and epidemics. The Indicator considers demographic characteristics, such as pressures from high population growth rates or skewed population distributions, such as a ?youth or age bulge,? or sharply divergent rates of population growth among competing communal groups, recognizing that such effects can have profound social, economic, and political effects. Beyond the population, the Indicator also takes into account pressures stemming from natural disasters (hurricanes, earthquakes, floods or drought), and pressures upon the population from environmental hazards., The Demographic Pressures Indicator considers pressures upon the state deriving from the population itself or the environment around it. For example, the Indicator measures population pressures related to food supply, access to safe water, and other life-sustaining resources, or health, such as prevalence of disease and epidemics. The Indicator considers demographic characteristics, such as pressures from high population growth rates or skewed population distributions, such as a �youth or age bulge,� or sharply divergent rates of population growth among competing communal groups, recognizing that such effects can have profound social, economic, and political effects. Beyond the population, the Indicator also takes into account pressures stemming from natural disasters (hurricanes, earthquakes, floods or drought), and pressures upon the population from environmental hazards.

P1082.label: population
P1082.description: number of people inhabiting the place; number of people of subject

P1098.label: number of speakers
P1098.description: number of people who speak a language

P1125.label: Gini coefficient
P1125.description: measure of statistical dispersion intended to represent the income distribution of a nation's residents

P1193.label: prevalence
P1193.description: portion of a population with a given disease

P1198.label: unemployment rate
P1198.description: portion of a workforce population that is not employed

P1279.label: inflation rate
P1279.description: percent change in the consumer price index (CPI)
aliases: inflation rate of consumer price index

P1538.label: number of households
P1538.description: total number of households in this place, includes dwellings of all types

P1539.label: female population
P1539.description: number of female people inhabiting the place; number of female people of subject

P1540.label: male population
P1540.description: number of male people inhabiting the place; number of male people of subject

P1689.label: central government debt as a percent of GDP

P2130.label: cost
P2130.description: amount of money spent on building or producing an object

P2131.label: nominal GDP
P2131.description: market value of all officially recognized final goods and services produced within a country in a given period of time

P2132.label: nominal GDP per capita
P2132.description: country's total GDP divided by the population

P2133.label: total debt
P2133.description: amount of debt for a company, organization or public entity

P2134.label: total reserves
P2134.description: total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities

P2135.label: total exports
P2135.description: amount of goods and services sold to other countries

P2136.label: total imports
P2136.description: amount of goods and services bought from other countries

P2137.label: total equity
P2137.description: amount of equity value for an entity

P2138.label: total liabilities
P2138.description: total liabilities for a corporation or entity

P2139.label: total revenue
P2139.description: income gained by an organization during a given time frame. not to be confused with fiscal revenue

P2140.label: foreign direct investment net outflow
P2140.description: net outflow of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital

P2141.label: foreign direct investment net inflow
P2141.description: net inflow of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital

P2197.label: production rate
P2197.description: amount of produced in a given time

P2218.label: net worth
P2218.description: estimated totality of wealth possessed by a person

P2219.label: real gross domestic product growth rate
P2219.description: percentage change in nominal GDP from one year to the next minus the inflation rate

P2226.label: market capitalization
P2226.description: total value of issued shares by a publicly traded company

P2232.label: cash
P2232.description: the value of cash and securities held by a state government

P2250.label: life expectancy
P2250.description: life expectancy for this group or species

P2284.label: price
P2284.description: published price listed or paid for a product (use with unit of currency)

P2292.label: consumption rate
P2292.description: rate at which a product is consumed

P2294.label: balance of trade
P2294.description: exports minus imports. not to be confused with current account balance and balance of payments

P2296.label: money supply
P2296.description: amount of currency the central bank has injected in the economy (MO, M1, M2, M3)

P2299.label: PPP GDP per capita
P2299.description: GDP divided by the population total and adjusted for CPI
aliases: GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity
gross domestic product (at purchasing power parity) per capita

P2402.label: total expenditure
P2402.description: amount of spending by this public or private entity, not to be confused with fiscal expenditure

P2403.label: total assets
P2403.description: value of assets held by a private or public entity

P2555.label: fee
P2555.description: fee or toll payable to use, transit or enter the subject (only for one-time fees, do NOT use it for an ongoing fee, tuition fee or trading fee)

P2573.label: number of out-of-school children
P2573.description: number of out-of-school children reported for a place
aliases: number of out of school children

P2630.label: cost of damage
P2630.description: monetary value of damage caused by this event

P2661.label: target interest rate
P2661.description: benchmark interest rate of the central bank

P2662.label: consumption rate per capita
P2662.description: rate of consumption of a product divided by the population

P2663.label: common equity tier 1 capital ratio (CETI)
P2663.description: relation between the core capital or shareholder's equity of a Bank and its risk-weighted assets

P2769.label: budget
P2769.description: assigned monetary amount for a project (for the estimated cost of a film, also commonly referred to as budget, use P2130)

P2834.label: individual tax rate
P2834.description: percentage tax rate on individuals by income

P2835.label: lowest income threshold
P2835.description: lowest income for which the tax rate applies, qualifier for P2834 (individual tax rate)

P2836.label: highest income threshold
P2836.description: highest income for which the tax rate applies, qualifier for P2834 (individual tax rate)

P2855.label: VAT-rate
P2855.description: percentage value-added tax in this country or region. Do not use for sales tax. For specialised rates, use qualifiers

P3087.label: fiscal/tax revenue
P3087.description: fiscal revenue of a public entity

P3618.label: base salary
P3618.description: gross salary of a position or a person (not including bonuses or other forms of remuneration)

P3744.label: number of subscribers
P3744.description: number of subscribers for subscription based companies, e.g. telecommunication companies, newspapers, pay-TV channels, etc.

P3864.label: suicide rate
P3864.description: amount of suicides per 100,000 people in the place or group

P3934.label: face value
P3934.description: value printed on a coin, stamp or banknote by the issuing authority

P4010.label: GDP (PPP)
P4010.description: Gross domestic product (GDP) at purchasing power parity (current international $)

P4103.label: assets under management
P4103.description: total market value of financial assets which a financial institution manages on behalf of its clients and itself

P4131.label: annual energy output
P4131.description: annual energy output of a power plant

P4841.label: total fertility rate
P4841.description: average number of children that would be born to a woman over her lifetime

P5982.label: annual number of weddings
P5982.description: number of marriages per year in a location

P6343.label: urban population
P6343.description: number of people living within the territorial entity who live in its urban parts

P6344.label: rural population
P6344.description: number of people living within the territorial entity who live in its rural parts

P6498.label: illiterate population
P6498.description: number of illiterate people within a territorial entity (typically determined during a census)

P6639.label: capacity factor
P6639.description: percentage of maximum power output provided on average by a given power station or power generation unit

P6794.label: minimum wage
P6794.description: lowest wage which can be paid legally in a state for working

P6826.label: feed-in tariff
P6826.description: monetary value in a given currency, where a renewable power station gets paid for the amount of power they generate

P100004.label: military expenditure (% of general government expenditure)
P100004.description: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)

P100005.label: military expenditure (% of GDP)
P100005.description: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)

P100006.label: employment to population ratio, 15+, total (%) (national estimate)
P100006.description: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Employment is defined as persons of working age who, during a short reference period, were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period (i.e. who worked in a job for at least one hour) or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangements. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.

P100010.label: consumer price index (2010 = 100)
P100010.description: Consumer price index reflects changes in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used. Data are period averages.

P100014.label: economic decline and poverty
P100014.description: The Economic Decline Indicator considers factors related to economic decline within a country. For example, the Indicator looks at patterns of progressive economic decline of the society as a whole as measured by per capita income, Gross National Product, unemployment rates, inflation, productivity, debt, poverty levels, or business failures. It also takes into account sudden drops in commodity prices, trade revenue, or foreign investment, and any collapse or devaluation of the national currency. The Economic Decline Indicator further considers the responses to economic conditions and their consequences, such as extreme social hardship imposed by economic austerity programs, or perceived increasing group inequalities. The Economic Decline Indicator is focused on the formal economy ? as well as illicit trade, including the drug and human trafficking, and capital flight, or levels of corruption and illicit transactions such as money laundering or embezzlement., The Economic Decline Indicator considers factors related to economic decline within a country. For example, the Indicator looks at patterns of progressive economic decline of the society as a whole as measured by per capita income, Gross National Product, unemployment rates, inflation, productivity, debt, poverty levels, or business failures. It also takes into account sudden drops in commodity prices, trade revenue, or foreign investment, and any collapse or devaluation of the national currency. The Economic Decline Indicator further considers the responses to economic conditions and their consequences, such as extreme social hardship imposed by economic austerity programs, or perceived increasing group inequalities. The Economic Decline Indicator is focused on the formal economy � as well as illicit trade, including the drug and human trafficking, and capital flight, or levels of corruption and illicit transactions such as money laundering or embezzlement.

P100015.label: uneven economic development
P100015.description: The Uneven Economic Development Indicator considers inequality within the economy, irrespective of the actual performance of an economy. For example, the Indicator looks at structural inequality that is based on group (such as racial, ethnic, religious, or other identity group) or based on education, economic status, or region (such as urban-rural divide). The Indicator considers not only actual inequality, but also perceptions of inequality, recognizing that perceptions of economic inequality can fuel grievance as much as real inequality, and can reinforce communal tensions or nationalistic rhetoric. Further to measuring economic inequality, the Indicator also takes into account the opportunities for groups to improve their economic status, such as through access to employment, education, or job training such that even if there is economic inequality present, to what degree it is structural and reinforcing.

P100016.label: human flight and brain drain
P100016.description: The Human Flight and Brain Drain Indicator considers the economic impact of human displacement (for economic or political reasons) and the consequences this may have on a country?s development. On the one hand, this may involve the voluntary emigration of the middle class ? particularly economically productive segments of the population, such as entrepreneurs, or skilled workers such as physicians ? due to economic deterioration in their home country and the hope of better opportunities farther afield. On the other hand, it may involve the forced displacement of professionals or intellectuals who are fleeing their country due to actual or feared persecution or repression, and specifically the economic impact that displacement may wreak on an economy through the loss of productive, skilled professional labor., The Human Flight and Brain Drain Indicator considers the economic impact of human displacement (for economic or political reasons) and the consequences this may have on a country�s development. On the one hand, this may involve the voluntary emigration of the middle class � particularly economically productive segments of the population, such as entrepreneurs, or skilled workers such as physicians � due to economic deterioration in their home country and the hope of better opportunities farther afield. On the other hand, it may involve the forced displacement of professionals or intellectuals who are fleeing their country due to actual or feared persecution or repression, and specifically the economic impact that displacement may wreak on an economy through the loss of productive, skilled professional labor.

P100022.label: external intervention
P100022.description: The External Intervention Indicator considers the influence and impact of external actors in the functioning ? particularly security and economic ? of a state. On the one hand, External Intervention focuses on security aspects of engagement from external actors, both covert and overt, in the internal affairs of a state at risk by governments, armies, intelligence services, identity groups, or other entities that may affect the balance of power (or resolution of a conflict) within a state. On the other hand, External Intervention also focuses on economic engagement by outside actors, including multilateral organizations, through large-scale loans, development projects, or foreign aid, such as ongoing budget support, control of finances, or management of the state?s economic policy, creating economic dependency. External Intervention also takes into account humanitarian intervention, such as the deployment of an international peacekeeping mission., The External Intervention Indicator considers the influence and impact of external actors in the functioning � particularly security and economic � of a state. On the one hand, External Intervention focuses on security aspects of engagement from external actors, both covert and overt, in the internal affairs of a state at risk by governments, armies, intelligence services, identity groups, or other entities that may affect the balance of power (or resolution of a conflict) within a state. On the other hand, External Intervention also focuses on economic engagement by outside actors, including multilateral organizations, through large-scale loans, development projects, or foreign aid, such as ongoing budget support, control of finances, or management of the state�s economic policy, creating economic dependency. External Intervention also takes into account humanitarian intervention, such as the deployment of an international peacekeeping mission.
